author: Super_Mario_64
title: Protecter of Water-the Matoran were better.
review:
I acquired the Protector of Water a few weeks ago, and I was mildly impressed. Not enough to make me want to go out and by another Protector though.

Box/Instructions

The box is alright, the ergonomic design is a good thing, but it is WAY too flimsy.

 

Parts

The parts are average, with the mask being the best piece included.

 

The build

 

It's a rather easy model; my little brother was able to put it together perfectly.

 

The completed model

 

The Protector of Water, as all the other Protectors are, is rather small. Some of the armour pieces look a bit off, and I've already switched some pieces around to make it look better.

 

Overall opinion

This isn't a bad set, but it isn't too good either. I wouldn't really recommend getting it, unless you want all the BIONICLE sets. I don't know why they decided to go with the Protectors instead of the Matoran. The Matoran all had unique stories and were a lot more diverse. The Protectors feel like mindless, souless robots who have no free will. I'll be interested how LEGO attempts to create a legitimate story with these guys. This new BIONICLE will never be as good as the original.

author: xboxtravis7992
title: Protector of Water
review:
My second Bionicle purchase since the start of the new reboot, the Protector of Water has a lot of good features and a few downsides. Let's dive in shall we?

First though, I feel it is worth noting what is this guy's place in Bionicle's story. Seeing that a large part of the appeal of Bionicle comes from the story, I think it is worth brief mention; especially seeing that the Protector's roles are not as easily noted as are the Toa or the Villains. First this Protector is named Kivoda something not listed on the box or the set title. Kivoda is also a male, breaking up the former Bionicle tradition that "all good guys who are blue are female." (Apparently the Protector of Earth is a female, again showcasing the changes in the new rebooted story.)  According to Biosector01 Kivoda got his title from his late father. 

Okay, that is enough of the story, onto the actual set.

Parts

The blue protector mask is the standout part here, and a lot of other parts come in a nice dark trans blue and light trans blue colors. The Skull Spider comes in silver, a color also available in at least 4 other Bionicle sets.

The build

A simple build. This is though a lot beefier than Bionicle's previous Matoran/Agori/Turaga builds. However seeing that the model is worth $10 dollars, maybe it would be more appropriate to compare it to the classic Toa sets than the Matoran sets... 

Either way, the build has few surprises and is quickly finished.

The completed model

This Protector looks good, the basic shells are very sleek, and the main silver shell on the torso provides a nice armored look on top of the smoother pieces. I am divided on the weapon, I like how it looks like a device to propel the Protector through the water, yet I dislike how it forces the Protector to hold it with both hands. The detractor of the model is the turbine propellers on the shoulders, they are just kind of ridiculous, and dwarf the Protector with their size.

Overall opinion

This is a good model, but not an outstanding one. If I had the money I would buy multiples to build villagers to accompany the Toa and Protectors, but seeing that my funds are tight I don't have enough reason to justify a second purchase. If this model does anything, it is that it serves a complement to the Toa, as a source of wisdom or support. This is an average set, get it if you are into Bionicle and want to complete a set of with the six Protectors, or if you want parts to build villagers. The price is good, and would make a great "stocking stuffer" for any parent who needs a Bionicle gift for their kid this Christmas (It also makes a great impulse buy for a cash strapped college student like me). So yeah, that is The Protector of Water, he's a solid buy, but not anything to get to excited about.
